review_title: Working as a Sessional lecturer at UofT
pros: It is an okay job for when you first finish your phd and have a post-doc. You make approximately $7500 per course taught. I think it's above average compared to colleges. It's also unionized so there's an avenue to resolve grievances. You also get some small benefits through the union for health expenses (about $500).
cons:
It's not really a job you want for a long time. It's easy to get stuck in it. Not a living wage. You can't apply for research grants from tricouncil. I'm only able survive because I also have a CIHR post-doc. In hindsight, it may have been better to not teach and focus on my post-doc and get those publications out so I can get a real tenure-track job. 

My students are pretty self-entitled. One student consistently does not show up to class, and when he did badly on an assignment, he went to complain to the chair that my assignment was too difficult. The chair then asked me to conduct 2 student evaluations to make sure the students were okay with the course. Most students like the course, but it was a very stressful experience for me.

review_title: The 2 year limit of financial support for M.Sc. graduate students is outdated and too short. Undergrad experience sucks.
pros:
- Top research (depending on your supervisor)
- Heart of downtown Toronto
- Prestige (especially for grad school)
- Lots of research going on
cons:
- 2 year limit for graduate students (MSc) is too short as the research for MSc degrees now often takes 3 years to complete. You may end up with 1 year of no financial support for research that basically powers the university (I find that very unfair); moreover, you get charged $8000+ tuition for that year while not getting paid anything, even though you're not taking any courses but mainly working for the university (a crappy unpaid internship-like experience with long hours).

- Don't go here for undergrad. My GPA was 3.95 in my 4th year, but it's just not worth it as it is MUCH riskier to get a high grade here than any other university in Canada and there is barely any culture (unless you're in PhysEd). Being an undergrad at UofT is just a bad experience for most people. Undergrad is like high school nowadays. It doesn't matter where you go as long as you get the grades you need and learn what you want to learn.

pros:
The academic environment at UofT is quite good and very stimulating; there are many interesting student groups and generally the opportunity to interact with smart people.
Research at UofT is very good, too, and departments invite many high profile scientists, which provides many opportunities to learn and to network; getting to know scientists in other high profile institutions is very important!
cons:
There are two main complaints I have and they are related. The first is that graduation times are far too long: it is not unusual for a PhD to take 7 years or longer at UofT! This is largely because graduate students are abused for cheap labor, either as TAs or research/lab assistants and professors don't have areal incentive to let a well trained senior graduate student graduate.
The other is that there is little to foster industry connections and inform students about careers outside of academia. Professors essentially expect their students to pursue an academic career and are not very helpful otherwise.

pros: Good Pay and flexible schedule
cons: Hard to get promotion here

pros: The University of Toronto looks great on your resume.  Nice coworkers.  Nice facilities.  Impressive faculty.  Good library system.  Functional classrooms.
cons:
University claimed postdocs were not employees; result: severe tax consequences for anyone being honest, inability to file for EI benefits, and difficulty with some immigration issues.  Postdocs tried to unionize, and the university tried to scare us by, among other things, threatening to take more from our paychecks.  I left soon after a successful vote for unionization.

Had responsibilities at more than one campus, forcing a long commute.  Underpaid for a professional job in Toronto.  Not one teaching evaluation from anyone other than students, and had to fight to actually receive those.  Asked to teach classes that students are woefully unprepared for, because "U of T has to be hard".  Caught several students cheating, and the punishment was inconsistent.  Was asked to grade a few final exams without pay after my contract finished and I could no longer legally work in Canada; I'm quite certain this is illegal.

pros: You certainly get access to great resources and great people, and the opportunities to lever this for yourself are large.  The whole University community - from libraries to gyms to social clubs - is impressive, and you'll be surrounded by many of the best in the business.  The U of T is one hell of a great machine when it swings into motion.  Pay is good, but beware labour issues - several strikes/arbitrations in recent years.
cons: It's a snake pit.  People are extremely competitive, extremely petty, and the stakes are low; if you expect to be treated kindly you'll be frustrated.  You need to have internal motivation and internal rewards to succeed here, because you'll wait forever for a pat on the back.  Collaboration is generally kept to a minimum, despite rhetoric to the contrary, and territorialism is the order of the day.  Frequently hamstrung by baffling inefficient bureaucracy.

pros: Salary, location, fantastic library system.
cons: Work-life balance for a Professor at UofT is better described as work-work-work. The pressure to produce publishable research and obtain grants is enormous. Yes, this is one of the primary jobs of a professor but the emphasis on research detracts from the time and capacity to teach effectively, let alone serve on committees and participate in community life. The workplace culture is competitive and isolating; even as all professors face the same overwhelming pressure there is no time or incentive to support one another. The same goes for supporting students. I got into academia because I really enjoy teaching, wanted to pursue participatory pedagogy, and genuinely care about my students. UofT, I feel, does not. Students are treated numbers and to the University administration, that's what they are, with $ attached. I really felt that teaching had no value to the administration and in order to get ahead I had to devalue it myself. Fortunately, I'm now at a smaller institution where I am still able to research (and publish on) my areas of passion while also pursuing my passion for teaching.

review_title: A great place to work, as long as you can put up with the typical bureaucracy and lethargy of a large institution.
pros: Excellent benefits, competitive salaries, great professional development. Lots of variation between departments, in terms of work environment and types of jobs. At the Scarborough Campus, there is a pretty good culture of collegiality and collaboration. Also, the campus is constantly growing, which allows for positional growth and new opportunities.
cons: It's an enormous institution full of levels of bureaucracy and red tape. While your department might be forward-thinking and nimble, the 'approval process' to move on opportunities can be painfully slow. This can be entirely frustrating and de-motivating. Also, many issues can easily 'fall through the cracks', leaving workers in lower-level positions feeling forgotten as they wait for upper management to make decisions.

pros: Students are very bright, the work is interesting, other contract staff are wonderful, hardworking and generous
cons: Contract faculty do over 50% of the teaching but only 4% (or less) of the school's budget goes to paying us. The union is very weak (instructed contract faculty to take 1% raise instead of striking, after 12 years with no raise -- not even cost of living), full time faculty and management is snotty and condescending and treat contract faculty like anonymous dirt, though we do the same job (for a third of the price). There is no room for advancement. Of course this is the same story as you will hear at many other universities and colleges in North America, but is more depressing for the fact that U of T is in the top ten employers on the Sunshine List. Do something else if you can.

review_title: AccessAbility Services department  at UTSC has a great mission but poor leadership
pros: AccessAbility Services at UTSC has a strong department mission. Friendly and small campus. Opportunity to apply for internal jobs in other UofT campuses or departments once you are a full-time employee.
cons: Suggestions and creativity are discouraged. Expect an immediately negative and defensive answer if a full-time employee makes a suggestion. When issues arise, staff are immediately blamed. Blame happens before seeking more information about the situation. No room for advancement in this department. This is because innovative ideas are not welcomed. Employees are not seen for their potential. Advice from previous employees is to be silent, to nod and smile, while you transition to another department, campus or another organization that sets you up for success and values your suggestions. Staying silent seems to be the only behaviour that is welcomed.

review_title: Great Community for Graduate Students in the Sciences
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros: There is a lot of support for graduate students, particularly international students (which applies to me), both financially and socially. It is largely department-dependant and I can only speak to Science/Engineering, but the administration really seems to care about making sure that we are well supported to do the research we came here to do
cons: I think the pay is a bit below average compared to US Universities and the cost of living in Toronto is pretty high. I also think in the humanities/social sciences, they are not treated nearly as well as the Science/Engineering side (though, sadly, I think that's pretty standard across the board in most schools).

review_title: Graduate studies at U of Toronto
pros:
Well known, so hopefully if you survive your degree may have some weight, 
The highest rank in Canada and one of the top in North America
Great libraries. health services, beautiful old buildings.
Location, location, location...
cons:
High life expenses compared with the stipends,
Political atmosphere (while sometimes you can find genuinely helpful people, the norm is not to trust; the bright side is if you survive you can make sure that you are good in social politics compared with average grad students (kidding)),
It is not easy to find help when you are in real trouble, both professionally and personally; no real support system for grad students,
Tuition is quite heavy compared with other Canadian Universities and the stipend.
No real support for public transport of students (even after the very minimal student discount you have to pay over $110/month for the TTC pass and no reimbursement. So while housing prices in downtown are beyond imagination expensive for grad students, renting place outside downtown won't help too, since you'd need TTC pass that makes up for whatever you save on your rent).

review_title: Great work environment, family-friendly, lots of interesting positions, and great benefits
pros:
- Work environment
- Location (St. George)
- Family-friendly policies and practices
- Great health and educational benefits
- Ability to learn and grow in your career
- Professional and friendly workforce
cons:
- Some offices don't have the most up-to-date technology/ don't utilize new technology. Mainly due to the size of the University it takes time to roll out to everyone
- Complicated pay system
- Some offices can operate like a silo and not embody the great culture that is present in most offices
- Due to the size of the University, important updates can get lost in the mass of communication like different emails and list serves for office, department, faculty, University-wide, employee group specific recurring emails plus special memo distributions. Individuals are more often than not part of multiple lists and groups. A more consolidated communication approach would be better.

review_title: Good culture and work environment but hiring and funding practices can sometimes be political and opaque
job_title: Recruitment Communications Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros: Good work environment and camaraderie with colleagues and supervisor. I feel that my work is meaningful and makes a difference, and I am proud to represent the university. If you are skilled at your work-study job as an undergraduate, you can be hired easily again the next year and there are opportunities for advancement in certain non-academic departments past graduation.
cons: Work-study jobs are minimum wage and hours worked are capped at 12 hours per week, and even though the school year does not end until the end of April, the work-study program only runs until the end of February, when it becomes your department's responsibility to fund 100% of your wage. Due to internal politics, some departments do not have funding to retain work-study students until the end of the year, yet their students in unionized positions can keep working with a higher wage and no hour limit.

job_title: Integration Engineer, Space Flight Laboratory in Toronto, ON
pros:

cons:

review_title: Difficult to move up, great for lateral moves.
pros: The University of Toronto is a reputable place to work and they provide great benefits including tuition reimbursement.
cons: It is very very hard to move up within the University of Toronto.  Many of my colleagues agree that age is a huge factor when assessing wether you move into a role, even if the qualifications are more than met.  In present times for certain roles I have noticed gender to play a huge part as well.  Officially the university is trying to portray an unbiased view of itself with it's staffing.  Unfortunately, the official portrayal and reality often don't match.  Not a place for moving up.  Great for lateral moves.

pros:
It's the best school (arguably) in Canada, so if at the end of the day, having a diploma from this school gives me an edge over others during my job hunt, then yes, this would have been worth it (but the jury's still out on that one).

Great institution, great community of people in my field.  I'm in bioengineering, so being downtown amongst the university and all the adjacent hospitals is something that not a lot of schools can offer.  Great (multiple) facilities for fluorescent and live imaging.
cons: It's a downtown campus in one of the most expensive cities in the world.  I think our PhD stipends are competitive with other schools in Canada, but when you consider that downtown rent for a one-bedroom or even a studio apartment closes in on $2000/month, you may want to make sure that your savings account is in good shape before making a 6-year commitment.

pros: Great facilities (Robarts!), campus in the middle of a vibrant city, and potential for enormous intellectual growth made it worth for me. It really depends on the field but for modern languages U of T is highly respected which helps when on the market. I met some amazing colleagues too. Good, although not outstanding, career services
cons: Good luck surviving on 15 k in Toronto. Lots of people had to take up more RA/TA work and ended finishing pretty late. Also, I had no work-life balance and many of the people I met were on anti-depressant at some point. Had a bad experience at the Health Center (as an international). While the overall level in the humanities was good, some faculty members haven't really updated their methodology since the 1980s.

pros:
For some reason UofT still is considered a place to study and work.
Access to papers, library, analytical equipment, although not current or new is better than average.
People think you are smart because you work there.
cons:
Leadership by fear, abusive behavior and nepotism. RAs are incompetent, they are not there to help but to find problems. Academics are very territorial and even have disputes over funding and laboratory space. Offices are infested with mice! Too many students pick up office furniture from the street and bring it. No personal computers or printers. Laboratory space is insufficient and messy. Changes are useless because PIs don't pay attention to research or students. Very low pay and temporal. Preferential treatment to people from same cultural background as the PI.
There are rumors that Forestry is going to disappear. Too much gosip.

pros: Fist and foremost, research is a free-form pursuit: that means I can choose whatever interests me (subject to approval by my Adviser, of course), and the potential for personal growth is amazing. I also get to set my own hours, which is a great bonus. I must also mention that unlike many other places at UofT, the Physics Department is very caring and supportive towards its students.
cons: The academic job market can be bleak at the end of a fulfilling time working towards a PhD. The stipend is not something that will make anyone rich -- but it is certainly not something to complain about in Physics, as people in other disciplines have it much worse.

review_title: University of Toronto Scarborough ranks number one is job threat and dissatisfied staff members across all departments.
pros: Work environment is a definitely an asset. Meeting people on a daily basis and interacting with many brilliant minds across three campuses. Workshops and seminars are an asset.
cons: University of Toronto is very stingy on all aspects of employment. The reason (from higher up) is because of its ties to St. George campus, who ultimately dictate funding and any expenses per department despite Scarborough operating as a separate institution. Not only staff have been let go, but entire departments also. The campus has tripled in size but the number of staff the same. Tremendous amount of politics, so much politics that it affects the efficiency of staff.

pros: The professors at the University of Toronto are among the best in the world in their fields. U of T is a top research institute which attracts expert staff and high quality grad students. The research publications from UofT are among the highest ranked in the world. A Postdoctorate research position at UofT allows access to state of the art facilities and superior leadership and mentoring, fostering an excellent environment for high quality research. The compensation is standard for a postdoctoral position.  Toronto is a great city and a nice place to live during your postdoc experience.
cons: Like all postdoctoral fellowships, the compensation is not great. This cannot really be considered a con for the university because it is fairly standard across North America.

review_title: A place for productivity and innovation to die
pros: Pay, job security, benefits, lots of events on campus and amazing inspiring work happening
cons: It’s a big place so every faculty / dept is different but from what I’ve experienced the university is a place that hires mediocre people to positions of power and they stay for decades.  The security means turnover is limited but when people are poor leaders - it destroys great work and you are stuck with them.  The politics and red tape is stifling.  Bullying is rife but it’s conducted in such a way so as not to flag concerns to union staff.  The place will drive you insane if you want efficiency or effectiveness in your work. Everything requires 20 peoples sign off.  Change is not welcome here. Fit the mold or leave

pros: Excellent benefits; salaries higher than other post secondary schools in the GTA; discounted metro passes; benefits include discounted courses; closed during Christmas and staff are paid for that time, the university itself has a great vibe
cons:
Faculty of Pharmacy:  management uses their power to belittle admin staff e.g. answering emails during a scheduled meeting while admin person sits and waits.

The culture at the Faculty of Pharmacy is miserable: a colleague succumbed to cancer and her death went unacknowleged; racism goes unaddressed; unionized workers abuse the generous sick days, e.g. missing 80+ days of work out of approx. 250 business days in Onatario;

pros:
I am a graduate student in BioZone of the Chemical Engineering Department. 
The environment is really good, with friendly people. There are guaranteed TA hours available per term if you want them (as a MASc and Ph.D. student), and those TA hours pay well. The student association (CEGSA) is extremely active with many social and academic events with free food.

Benefits are OK considering that I am a graduate student.
cons: U of T is a large institution, meaning that you may have to deal with red tape. Be prepared to take a few weeks for the safety approval, meaning that if you start earlier, you can get this done earlier.

review_title: What you get out of a postdoc position depends mostly on you. Be a leader and show the world what you can do.
pros: Try to get as much publications as possible, get to know people and build a good relationship with your supervisor. Excellent research facilities, although office space may be a below standards. Flexible hours means you have a very good balance work/life.
cons: A postdoc is not a position to linger but to move forward as fast as possible. Consider this if you are willing to do one. Paying taxs is a pain. No benefits or unemployment benefits means that when your employment expires you will have no money. New grants for postdocs are awesome in Canada.

pros: Very good work environment. It is safe, you are given appropriate guidance on your work, and you feel rewarded by the results of your research. There are also a number of symposiums and opportunities to showcase your work at the end of the summer.
cons: Not all experience were like mine, some positions had less focused goals and thus consisted of more "busywork" than actual research. Hit or miss when it comes to this, and ends up changing the whole experience.

review_title: Good job opportunities, but administrators are at best, very restricted, and at worst, unhelpful and rude
pros: You are able to get great training at the University of Toronto. There are a lot of opportunities to explore your interests as a teaching assistant, as long as you are teaching at the satellite campuses (St. George campus' opportunities are more restricted due to high demand).
cons: You are severely restricted in the help you can offer students. You are also almost required to have an adversarial attitude towards all students, because usually, you will spend a disproportionate amount of time on your most troublesome students, while the good students do not take any of your time. Thus, you are restricted in your ability to be available and collaborative with students, especially if you are assisting in large courses.

review_title: Very good school to do research as a student
pros: If your research requires a lot of resources (both some form of data access or to a person who is an expert in the field), U of T is a great place to be in. Because of its large size and huge volume of books and journal articles, you are most likely to find what you want. It is also regarded as one of the top schools in the world for research.
cons: Because of the large size, it is hard to expect the type of environment in the suburbs or smaller universities. It is hard to know people other than the ones sit next to you or in your lab. Also, the quality of your life and experience is mostly dictated by your supervisor.

pros: St. George is a nice campus with lots of amenities and the city life. Some very nice people. Good wages.
cons: Most assignments had some dysfunctional situation to deal with. The worst was being belittle by management/direct supervisor -  this happen to me twice and it is very difficult because it takes time to recognize that it is happening and by then you have already be effected. I also witnessed many incidences of support staff treated badly. Was not allowed to work to my full potential as it was a threat to management. Culture is oppressive with a lot of micro-managing. Support staff are unsupported. Many faculties are still trying to set up systems.

review_title: Workstudies are Great Opportunity for Students
pros: I really valued my time at UofT during my work study time there. The 3 part time jobs I had were all fulfilling and honed my skills in a professional workplace, and the experience I got to take with me for a long, long time.
cons: The works study positions are great, but I wished that after I was hired, there'd be a small training event for work study students to network, learn professional skills, how to dress, how to interact with management etc. I felt like I was lacking in those skills and didn't make the most of my jobs there.

pros:
The working hours are very flexible hours,
Nice people to work with, 
Good insurance package
Good location (downtown) and close to subway
Great work-life balance
Can work at home
Number vacation days (1 month)
People
cons: Very low income considering your degree and your skills, not a permanent position, need to work on ad-hoc projects and train others, not considered priority for TAs, not a dynamic environment, not challenging enough, insecurity, you are not considered "expereince" for your future career, the experiments can be hazardous and not easy to operate device.

review_title: My experience working at  U of T
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros: I did my masters at U of T, which my department covered my tuition and provided me with many good opportunities to challenge myself. Also being a U of T employee, you get very good resources from the institution itself, although most are covered in the tuition in my case.
cons: I don't think there are any downsides working at U of T, except that if you are doing Masters, my department forced me to do TA, which I don't think it's a bad thing at all. But the fact that you have to do it to have your tuition covered had me feeling a little uncomfortable at first. Other than that, I felt pretty good working there.

pros: Large network of established scientists from various different fields who conduct cutting-edge science.  Large community of other postdoctoral fellows to give feedback and establish potential collaborative projects.  Toronto is a great, metropolitan city with many things to do outside of work.
cons: Not related to the University of Toronto in particular, however pay scale is low with respect to the level of education and the expected amount of work.  Require better support and career development for postdoctoral fellows at the University.

review_title: Fun work but be prepared for not knowing about similiar work is being done elsewhere on campus.
pros:
Stability and the change to work on large projects not available elsewhere.

Deadlines exist but there is latitude in determining how to approach and solve the problems.
cons:
Funding structure of divisions duplicates lots of things and there is little sharing of building block components between them.  Central IT is only 30% of the total and has the talk but little buy in from the divisions.

Telecomunications is run seperately from IT and is not responsive to small divisions.

Forced into giving $1000 per year to union for little benefit.

pros: Supervisors are very knowledgeable, helpful, and supportive. The equipment is really good and new. World class professors and students are at your fingertips.
cons: The hours you work are long and depending on your supervisor can be unrelated to your mail project. UofT is also a commuter school so it gets kinda dead and the sense of community is slightly diminished by that fact. Pay is meager at best, had to pick up side gigs to get by.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Toronto, ON
pros: Access to knowledge at your fingertips at the best institution in Canada.
cons:
I never pursued my own interests. I was attached to administrative detail for professors who didn't have time or resources to implement their own research projects, or desire to supervise entry-level graduate students.
The job market and current funding schemes also at the moment kind of suck - few positions available after the postdoc is done, and postdocs rarely qualify to fund their own work independently.

review_title: Working as library assistant in UofT
job_title: Circulation Desk Clerk in Toronto, ON
pros: Simple job that can get you enough money to pay rent so its not difficult to do it while being full time student! It is tough to get in because different libraries have different hiring cycles and past staff has seniority and will be returning to work in the Fall and Winter so its rare to find openings available. Try speaking with the circulation desk coordinator in early August for work in the Fall and Early December for work in Winter. Thank the Union for getting a pay higher than minimum wage.
cons: This job is only to help out with expenses. There is little to none intellectual challenge, social interaction or career advantage.

pros: Flexible hours, varied work leading to the development of numerous skills, downtown location, self-directed work with minimal oversight, opportunity to work with individuals from all over the world and observe full-scale structural experiments
cons: Sometimes requires weekend work to meet deadlines. Plenty of unsavory politics to navigate when working in the structural testing facility. Some equipment is outdated as well as the test methods used to conduct experiments.

review_title: Good, secure job, with lots of different opportunities"
job_title: Audio Visual Technician in Scarborough, ON
pros:
It is a Secure job with lots of different opportunities.  Full time employees have room to grow in a department, even switch into different departments.  
Very vibrant community, and a good working environment.  Organization has lots of programs and facilities for employees.

Competitive salaries.
cons: Internal politics meaning directors run the show despite not always being qualified.  There is minimal to no training for student employees.  Rather than training students to be better qualified they hire full time employees.

pros:
Flexible working times, interactive working environment
It helps to refresh knowledge about a specific course and gives free access to the course materials.
The TA union covers a percentage of the medical insurance
Profs are generally very friendly.
It is a great place for training verbal skills and developing behavioral kind of skills
Besides that it certainly will not interfere with the research work you are doing in the university.
cons:
Inconsistent working hours. Heavy marking job, 
Low wage and hours.
need extra time to prepare for the teaching sessions.
Generally, most students come in with very little or no knowledge about the course subject, This will usually take extra effort to teach them as well as marking their assignments.

pros:
•	Worked as a liaison between community and the Centre, interacting with community on a weekly basis via email and social medias, Twitter 
•	Prepared annual booklet and report that are delivered to the President Office UofT
•	Conducted extensive research of program enrolments from 2010 to 2015 for the Centre for Jewish Studies
•	Analyzed and interpreted qualitatively and quantitatively data that reflects the effectiveness of Facebook marketing, environments and student demands
•	Created surveys to discover the demands and interests of students who study Jewish Studies
cons: •	Planed and organized public events and conference that hold more than 100 people, and completed delegated assignments with the proactive aim of delivering service improvement and administrative cost savings

review_title: It's decent if you're into independence
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Toronto, ON
pros:
Top notch facilities, resources, and staff. Truly a pleasure to work around the best equipment and professionals.
Some sense of camaraderie.
Decent pay compared to other parts of the country (though expenses also higher).
cons:
Getting used to a life of comfort and having lots of resources at your disposal.
A lot is expected of you - can be good if you're constantly up for the challenge.
Can be intimidating for some to be constantly surrounded by high-achievers.

pros: Nothing good to say about this hell hole for grad students.
cons: The professors are extremely arrogant and abusive to grad students. They do not include them in research, as they are supposed to be training them to do research. Instead, they take brilliant people in who have tremendous qualifications and have them grade papers. They humiliate their grad students so that they become depressed and feel worthless and have lost all self esteem. Myself and others have experienced long term illnesses as a result. Stay away from UofT.

pros: Loads of scholarship, travel grant, research money available. If you're motivated, you can get a lot done. If you're not motivated, it will be a bit of a struggle.
cons: I'm a chemistry graduate student and the experience depends greatly on which sub-discipline you're in. The program requirements vary greatly between sub-diciplines. Some are very intensive and others leave you to carve your own path. Pros and cons to both. It's a good idea to figure out what kind of job you want early on in grad school and taylor your research towards preparing you for that.

job_title: Research Assistant At Rotman School of Management in Toronto, ON
pros:
- RAing is a good way to get to know professors and other students in your department
- Professors will consider your academic life and schedule your work around exams and classes so that the two are not in conflict
- Potential to participate in interesting studies, although this depends on the individual project itself that you are working for
cons:
- Salary is barely minimum wage
- If your supervisor is not very involved in the project, there is a potential for the experience to turn out somewhat lacklustre

pros: It has a Good Reputation. It looks good on a resume. The pay was pretty good, and you're part of a union. I worked on a research project and got my name on a major report. It's a pretty decent report and it involved many major corporations. It gave me an in with many people in those companies as well.
cons: The admin was a little confused and disorganized. The payment system they have was too inflexible and it ended up confusing everyone involved. The system also was not explained properly in the contract which let to more complications and confusion.

review_title: Not all that it presents itself to be.
pros: It's Canada, so a good work ethic is not totally necessary. If you are someone's friend, then you will have nothing to worry about as far as promoting and getting hired. Truthfully, you do have the best pool of students within N. America. You are working among an educated group of individuals.
cons: They will try anything in their power to make your job temporary. Unqualified people are put into roles of power and authority. There are too many administrators (they were someone's buddy). It is difficult to get a pay increase.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros: I did a 2-year research masters at UofT's Mechanical and Industrial Engineering Department. The faculty supervision was very strong and set me up well for my PhD later on. The RA/TA pay was sufficient to cover living expenses and there were opportunities to stack awards/scholarships on top of my base pay, so as far as student living goes I was pretty comfortable. Another pro is that the building is steps from the TTC (subway) and lots of food options are nearby.
cons: The mandatory seminar with guest lectures was kind of boring, mostly because the talks were too technical and hard to follow.

review_title: Amazing institution - in need of an overhaul for marketing and comms
pros: Great benefits, beautiful campus and generous vacation leave.
cons: Incredibly bureaucratic. The organization is sorely lacking expertise in digital and marketing, and leadership aren't equipped to even understand the skills gap let alone solve it. This is a very hierarchical, top-down org when it comes to leadership. If you're someone with ideas and ambition to drive change and improvement through your work - stay away.

pros: All postdoc positions depend heavily on the supervisor, but my experience has been very positive. The culture among faculty, staff, administrators, and students alike here is very friendly and supportive, even if typical academic beaurocracy is sometimes a problem. There are top notch resources available for research, collaboration, grant-writing, and more.
cons:
As is common in higher ed, administrative red tape is sometimes a problem, creating some obstacles to agile collaboration. 

Postdocs are currently classified as "academic trainees" rather than employees, limiting benefits and creating some challenges for international workers. This may be changing with the ongoing unionization process with CUPE.

review_title: Amazing opportunities to shape your career
pros: This university has the resources to allow you to train for just about any career.  The computer science department and math departments in particular are distinguished in North America.  The Molecular Genetics department is also very strong, with ties to many of the hospitals in the UHN.
cons: I wish the Computer Science department made more of an effort to engage with the burgeoning startup community in Toronto.  There are a lot of strong students here, I'm surprised that the department has not taken the initiative to forge links with local companies for internships.

pros: I have great colleagues at the university of Toronto. Most of them are educated professional people. Moreover, the payment has been always on-time and any time you have problem, there is a person to help you out. The hours are pretty flexible.
cons: It is not easy to get promotion in such a company. You usually have to keep your whatever position for many years. This is also true about the salary. you rarely get a raise.

job_title: Professor of Law in Toronto, ON
pros: Campus is beautiful; administration is professional; Toronto is a very good city for night life, to raise a family, to life a full life
cons: Toronto can be an expensive city to live in, especially as compared with smaller Canadian cities; the Toronto Transit Commission is so-so in providing subway and bus service compared to other world class cities

pros: The University of Toronto is a enjoyable place to work. the campus is well and convenienty located. I appreciated the Professionalism and would love to work there again. Progresses have been made in the past years in terms of accessibiity for all.
cons: there is not much negative points to say about it. However I would like to hear if equity in terms of remuneration has been addressed as there are still issues of stereotypes and discrimination making it difficult for certain groups to thrive.

review_title: University of Toronto - The Place to Work!
pros: The University of Toronto is quite correctly rated as one of the best employers in Canada. It's compensation packages are almost impossible to beat as are all the associated benefits, vacation time, pension plan, etc.
cons: Like all large institutions, it can be at times somewhat impersonal and difficult to navigate. But that is often easily overcome with time and an investment of effort on the part of the employee.

review_title: Started great but the wheels were coming off when I left
pros:
Fantastic physical environment. You are working in a park and your benefits package gives you access most places on campus (two gyms, Faculty Clubs, etc...)
Discounted tuition for non-professional faculties.

Free tuition to the School of Continuing Studies.

When I worked there, they were in the midst of what would become the largest philanthropic campaign in Canadian history. It was a very exciting time on campus, with a lot going on and access to some of the greatest minds in Canada and the world. One afternoon I found myself, a fairly junior staff member at the time, dining at Massey College with two Nobel winners and a Fielding Prize winner.
cons:
After the fundraising campaign ended, the administration encouraged those who had worked on the campaign not to leave for other universities and other campaigns, as is the norm, as U of T would be starting another campaign within two years. Due to a number of factors, that didn't happen and those of us who had stuck around were shipped around to special projects that didn't necessarily comport with our skills. When the admin finally decided to get rid of us as it would still be a while before starting the next campaign, a massive effort was made to constructively dismiss staff to avoid paying severance. In my department of eight people, seven had left within a year.

As others have mentioned, it is a big university that is largely decentralized so getting things done outside your college or faculty often involves wending your way through a labyrinth of staffers, many of whom seem to delight in serving as obstacles (particularly if you work for the central administration).

review_title: Good, as long as you keep track of your hours
pros: Good program, good benefits; research facilities and opportunities for research and interaction with the global academic community are numerous.
cons: The quality of one's experience largely depends on how engaged one's supervisor is ; students doing TA work would do well to track the amount of hours worked, as sometimes the estimated contracted workload and the real amount are very different, which can impact other parts of one's workload.

review_title: A great opportunity to gain lab experience and network with professors.
pros: UofT is one of the biggest research giants in North America. There are many opportunities to find a job in which one can contribute to scientific research and further advance scientific discoveries. The professors and grad students are great to work with, and never fail to help bring out the best in their employees.
cons: If you do not live in Toronto, the commute can be draining. It takes a good hour and a half to get downtown via transit, and transit systems run into problems frequently, so delays are expected.

review_title: A good start, but keep training & move on after 4 -5 years.
job_title: Lab Tech II in Toronto, ON
pros:
The work is interesting, always changing, constantly learning new techniques. Every Principle Investigator is different, some are horrible but I have a great boss.
U of T has OK benefits, good pension, good vacation time.
cons: The grant paid system means this job is insecure. You are basically a contract employee with benefits. There is no opportunity for promotion. You'd make more money for less aducation as a admin assistant, have more career paths and job security.

pros:
Research oriented work - gained research experience.
Learned a lot through the graduate courses I enrolled.
Gained teaching experience.
cons:
Lack of interest from supervisors and some faculty members.
Lack of interest and motivation from faculty members.
Lack of communication and no guidance from supervisors.

review_title: A Large and Well-Known University with a Beautiful Campus in the Middle of a Vibrant City
pros: The University of Toronto offers a very pleasant work environment. Postdocs can benefit of most of the students facilities and services even though they don't pay tuition fee.
cons: Compensation and management is very dependent of the supervisor and department. Also, the status of postdoctoral fellow is not clear: as  "trainees", they are neither students nor employees and the Canada Revenue Agency is still discussing whether postdocs income should be taxed or not.

pros: Benefits and salaries are good, large university with every program and amenity you can think of.  Students and colleagues are some of the best in the country.  Teaching is respected and research is well supported.
cons: Very spread campus, the big city can diminish the sense of community.  Old buildings can be pretty from the outside but can be challenging to operate and work in.

review_title: World class researchers; funding support mixed. Everything based on context (type of research/type of supervisor)
job_title: PhD Candidate (Industrial Engineering) in Toronto, ON
pros:
Recognized throughout the world, UofT is a great place to conduct research. You interact with bigwigs in your discipline and have the chance to make a global impact. There are great student support structures (you just have to seek them out) and the career office is doing a lot better about connecting students to jobs. They even conducted some sessions with phds outside of academia, becoming more and more a reality by the day. 

Depending on your supervisor you can have a great work/life balance or a frustrating one. Also, depending on your own dedication and work ethic it can take variable amount of time to finish and there may be extenuating circumstances that can affect how long you stay in the graduate degree (marriage, family commitments, change in research, etc.).

Finally, the benefits packages are pretty good you have a decent amount of coverage and a spending account (if you do TA work or teaching) that you can put toward major purchases (glasses, contacts, dentist, etc.)
cons: The payment scale is pretty bad. Especially compared to the real world. Most students and post-docs are paid below the poverty line and have to supplement their income with TAships or instructor positions if you can find one or contracts outside of the university. The career outlook for students in academia is not very good. We have an overabundance of highly educated people with no place for them to work. A lot of phds are entering the industry instead of academic gigs because the payment scale is much better and there are opportunities. On the industry side they have no idea how to use PHD level researchers nor how valuable our skills can be so the payment scales don't always match up. Sometimes it takes some convincing on your part.

pros: Research focused school will allow for bright minds to excel. Opportunities are abound through part time roles as a student and possibility to continue on in a different capacity in other departments upon graduation
cons: The university atmosphere isn't for all. It provides a lot of pros, however, if someone is looking for more of a corporate environment, this is not it.

review_title: Working as TA at UofT can be both challenging and rewarding at the same time!
job_title: Graduate Student/Teaching Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros: Working with students is a great way to improve interpersonal skills and your leadership skills. UofT is a well established university worldwide.
cons: I wish I had more hours to as a TA. I wish I had more time to dedicate to each student separately, at times it can get overwhelming to attend to a large student group at the same time.

review_title: Challenging, but with a wide variety of opportunities.
pros: Newest research equipment.  Plenty of funding for research.  Plenty of technical challenges.  Good social events.  Travel to international conferences.  Freedom to personalize research projects.
cons: Not personable supervisor.  Too much responsibility may be thrown your way.  Politically charged environment.  Working hours are defined by the success of your research; may not be regular and may be very long.

review_title: Front of House Manager - Isabel Bader Theatre
pros: Great work/life balance, tight-knit group, flexible hours and diverse events held at venue. The venue itself is aesthetically beautiful and patrons love the professionalism.
cons: Under-staffed, not equipped to be a full functioning arts venue - no concessions and washrooms only located on basement level. Backstage dressing rooms are spread out around a number of floors which makes it difficult for quick changes or easy access.

job_title: Computer Science PhD Student in Toronto, ON
pros: Fairly well known department/university internationally, with all the benefits that this entails. The computer science department guarantees funding for 5 years.
cons: While funding is guaranteed for 5 years, the compensation level is relatively low, especially after taking into account the cost of living in Toronto.

pros: -good environment, first-hand exposure to academia, laid-back, minimum wage but laissez-faire work style, supervisors (or professors) are friendly, allows you to take on responsibility and substantially contribute to a research project while also getting paid
cons:
-maybe more hands-on supervision
-depends on professor who is supervising you so experience can be quite variable
-hard position to get; usually reserved for grad or PhD students, so depends on whether the professor wants to hire you, which is based on how well you fit his/ her needs, hence the hiring practice isn't as standardized

review_title: Great place to learn and work
pros:
- Access to top tier researchers 
- Access to top tier equipment and facilities 
- Big school means there is always someone with the answer you are looking for
- Graduate departments/offices are always helpful
cons:
- It is a very large institution and it is easy to get lost in the mix 
- Lots of red tape
- Slow moving monolithic policies

pros: Good level of support when needed and friendly atmosphere within work team. The level of expertise allows the group to work together on solving problems which reflects back on the group well.
cons: University of Toronto is a big place, so it can become hard to find your identity within the larger faculty. But if your group is small and close enough, not a problem.

pros: Location, good benefits, good culture of professional development, good opportunities to move vertically and horizontally, salary is very good, innovation culture
cons: Location....if you are not a fan of traffic and a downtown location, its a very big institution, so it may not be for everyone, hiring is mostly done within the institution and low chance of new talent coming in

pros:
-Top tier program 
-Exposure to cutting edge research 
-Exposure to leading researchers
cons:
-Severely underpaid for the work and hours 
-Unfair inventorship and intellectual property policies 
-Supervisors may take advantage of you/ take credit for your work

review_title: Okay place to work - but big on bureacracy
pros: Good people, good hours, world-class place.  Lots of things to do in and around the school.  Feel like you make a difference
cons: Lack of real growth.  While x-departmental movement is possible, many find it difficult.  Very, very bureactratic - even in the organization tasked with growing donations!

pros: Getting able to work with world class researchers and professors who are passionate about their respective fields. The environment at the University of Toronto is one where challenge is constant, but excellence is always maintained.
cons: There are not many apparent cons for working at U of T. I can say nothing negative in regards to this: any potential negative may be caused by an incompatibility in my preferred work schedule, type of work done, etc, as opposed to being directly caused by the environment at U of T.

review_title: Not a bad place to work
pros: It really depends on the professor you work for.  Mine was very supportive and so were the other people I work for. The workload was fair and I never felt like I was being watched. More like "as long as it gets done" attitude.
cons:
- Graduate students in the lab were incredibly lazy
- Tenured profs can be rude and out of touch
- Some staff members were unfairly hired

review_title: Good place for a life science postdoctoral fellow
pros:
Well connected with hospitals and other research institutions
Access to plenty of journals online
Discounts at major companies (Rogers, Goodlife, etc)
cons:
Green Shield supplemental insurance barely covers dental and vision
Old campus buildings with confusing layout, narrow hallways and low ceilings
Athletic centre has poor equipment and has the same price as Goodlife
No shuttle buses to take you around during extreme weather

pros: Professors are nice and willing to help at anytime. I get practiced in explaining complicated ideas or concepts in an understandable way. The feeling worth more than the salary earned. UofT counts the working hour and pay the corresponding salaries in a very generous way.
cons: It takes a lot of individual time to get ready for the tutorial. Students ask about easy questions repeatedly and teaching assistants have to explain again and again.

job_title: Community Engagement Specialist in Toronto, ON
pros: As a TA, compensation was competitive (approx. $50/hour). Course I TA'd for provided weekly guide for leading tutorials and training in how to evaluate student assignments.
cons: I felt I was not allotted enough paid hours to prepare thoroughly or to evaluate student assignments. Often, I had to innovate classroom activities to compensate for ineffective tutorial guides, which I was happy to do, as it allowed me to develop my own pedagogical style. However, this required many hours of extra work, which I could not be paid for.

pros: Access to many of the best facilities at the school, as well as top-notch scientific equipment. Access to some great minds and leaders in their fields. Close to area hospitals and other research centers for accumulation of knowledge and face-to-face time with world leaders in many disciplines. Great name and place for future employment or graduate or professional school.
cons: However, prone to bureaucracy and slow responses. Not a great compensation package being a public institution.

job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros:
Fair compensation per hour as a TA
Accessible training programs
Top tier academic facilities
cons:
Inadequate compensation for research work
Insufficient career development / training options
Lack of engagement with coordinators as a TA
Lack of timely actionable feedback
Inconsistent hours

pros: Excellent area to be for research in the healthcare industry and medicine (large amount of funding programs available to the university).
cons: Typical of most research-oriented posts, there isn't a large focus on efficiency and pushing projects out the door, but more dwelling on how to improve things or make it better. Trade-off between output and quality.

review_title: Positive work atmosphere with inspiring minds at the Division of Anatomy!
pros: My employer at the division of anatomy helped me grow as a researcher by constantly providing constructive feedback. The academic culture at the division was conducive to learning and discovery. Research supervisors were highly supportive and allowed me to explore my own interests in the biological sciences.
cons: None (as an employee), but many woes as a student. Compensation could have been better.

pros:
-great working environment teaching students
-get to work from home when grading or preparing for tutorials
-Very good pay, one of the highest in Canada
cons: I did not see many downsides to working and the University of Toronto. The atmosphere is great, but sometimes it can be difficult dealing with students

pros: Great dynamic research environment, with exceptional level of funding and access to research facilities.
cons:
- Somewhat pretentious attitude about the institute; and occasionally focused more on the appeal of the research than the substance.

- There is an attitude of showing more (financial) appreciation for support and administrative staff more than for the academic staff whom ultimately fulfill the purpose of this institution.

pros: This is a good place to get yourself a professional researcher. If you are after research, UofT is the place to be in Canada. It has highest standards of teaching, research and funding.
cons: Some positions may not be that well-paid compared to what's possible in the industry. Such positions include post-doc, research associate, senior research associate and lab managing assistant etc.

review_title: University of Toronto receives bad grade
pros: Prestigious employer. Nice campus, beautiful buildings and grounds. Great to see motivated, enthusiastic young people exploring new intellectual territory and gaining life experience.
cons: Highly disfunctional workplace, from top down. Universities as a rule are highly political work environments (i.e. office politics) but this is a step beyond. One of the worst working environments I've seen.

pros: Being a T A allows one to have interaction with students, design curriculum, present your ideas, and help students learn material. The U of T has great compensation, is fair, flexible, and provides adequate training.
cons: Downsides are few, perhaps that work hours are limited to a few hours per week because of classes so you don't get "chunks" of time to work in.

pros: The labs and facilities are modern and spacious. Training for my work was provided by my supervisor prior to the start of the job. All aspects of the payroll were promptly managed by the payroll officer. Overall, everything was conducive to my learning experience as a part-time summer research assistant.
cons: The amount of pay is low, at 10.25 per hour plus 4 percent vacation bonus. Nonetheless, this is to be expected from a part time student position. The research experience was well worth it.

pros: Very large university with huge resources.  Collaborations are easy to establish and there are top notch scientists all around to provide advice when needed.
cons: Career advancement is not all too great.  Courses in graduate school are not as good as one would expect from a research-based university.

review_title: Great place filled with smart people, very supportive.
pros:
- Professors willing to coach and support Teaching Assistants
- Plenty of resources for teaching support, peers to help
- Compensation fair
- in Engineering department, small group setting and motivated students add to the experience
- Great experience for grad school applications
cons:
- the hours are not flexible, and get busiest when school itself is busiest: this can lead to some difficulty maintaining balance between work and actual studies
- occasionally motivated students that don't understand how they can get average grades

pros: Most positions are high paid and doesn't involve a lot of work so its always great to get one of those jobs. And its always a great experience to work under your department and professor - creates links with TA's and other profs.
cons: Not all positions give you experience related to what you thought it would and most positions fill up really quick. You'd need to apply as much as 6 months in advance about a position for the coming summer.

job_title: PhD Student (Medical Sciences) in Toronto, ON
pros:
-Bright profs, very research friendly environment, lots of opportunities and collaborations (medical sciences)
-Great location in the middle of the city, Toronto is a very lively metropolis
-Prestigious institution, a sense of pride and very up-beat
cons:
-Expensive living cost, especially given that you are paid the same as every other university in Canada that is located in small towns or in middle of no where
-Some times competition becomes overwhelming

pros: Great pay and benefits.  Good location flex hours , easy to get promoted if you know how to manage the right connections.  Immediate supervisors are very good to deal with.
cons: Top heavy with management.  More profit oriented then education oriented.   Somewhat cold atmosphere.  More of a cog with little recognition

pros: Smart people, great benefits, vacation, flex-time, interesting work. The software projects have real world applications and you can see their benefits.
cons: Depends a lot on your supervisor if you get opportunities to perform and show what you can do. Significant bureaucracy - things take forever to get agreement and decisions to be made. Resources can be scarce and technology can be slow to change.

review_title: massive administration stands in way of useful work
pros:
- independence
 - can be good if you have a good advisor
 - generally a calm and relaxed environment, casual dress, etc
 - this is very dependent on the faculty you are in
cons:
- massive administration, nothing can get done
 - they try to implement rules/procedures, which get ignored
 - individual faculty who should have retired years ago, don't. Not much the administration can do about them, they just suck up space for useful people.

pros: I've worked as a Teaching Assistant at this university and it's been a great experience. You have the opportunity to build meaningful connections with professors which are definitely helpful if you're looking for summer research positions, graduate school references or industry positions as well.
cons: You really need to stand out (either with a high GPA, work experience or both) in order to get noticed for teaching positions. Then again, this is the case for many positions in the industry as well.

review_title: U of T Work Study Central Administration
pros: Insightful work - you get to actually learn about the institutional operations that makes everything possible. It's a complex, decentralized organization which poses some interesting challenges and learning opportunities for work/study students.
cons: Minimum wage, and they cap your total hours at 200.

pros:
great benefit, good work life balance, very relaxing if you like to deal with students. 
salary is ok, but not good enough compared to industry
cons: too relaxing,....people around you don't work  that hard, it is a place for old people. you can never get a chance to be promoted unless someone died...

review_title: Assistant Computer Access Facility Attendant, Robarts Library
pros: Casual work environment with great benefits, located directly in the centre of campus. Supportive staff, great hours, and simple responsibilities.
cons: Sometimes it can be quite slow, so it can get a bit boring. Most of the time I would be able to do readings for class during slow periods, but time can drag on a bit.

pros:
At least in my experience:
- As much hands on work as you want
- Work can be as independent or grouped as you like
- Work your own hours, as long as you get your work done
- Good funding, never wanted for more research materials (within reason)
cons:
- Very dependent on your supervisor if you will have a good experience
- Sometimes hard to find courses that apply to your research
- Bureaucracy is always annoying, especially so at such a large university

review_title: I have been working at the department of Astronomy for 3 years now.
pros: Great collaborations, great students, lots of opportunities to meet people from around the world (weekly colloquium talks from big name astronomers). Best platform in Canada to launch yourself from if you want to become a researcher/ try and make it in academia.
cons: Faculty seem uninspired, which trickles down to the rest of the department. Many events are poorly attended, and there isn't as much energy/inspiration as one would have hoped.

pros: Good quality researchers, campus is great, generally well subventioned research (i.e., access to good research material)
cons: No scientific community exchange platform.  There is no ``integration`` when you arrive, so it takes time before you understand what is needed administratively-wise and what not.

pros: Universities are obviously great places to learn. What helped were the the people at the English Language Program. Great people, who I'm still friends with to this day.
cons: Room for growth is fairly difficult. You'd have to stay with the university for a very long time to see career progress. This is a good thing though, considering it's a prestigious University.

pros: Nice people, secure position, great benefits.  Salary is nothing to complain about either!
cons: Like most places, opportunities abound for the ones who can push paper the best.  Some people with ??? skills seem to flow seamlessly from senior job to even better senior job.

pros: great education, a lot of resources (such as libraries, gyms, teachers, career centre, etc). The students are, on the most part, great people.
cons: There is very little work/life balance. Studying often takes over your life. The material can be uncompromisingly difficult and obtaining high scores on tests is nearly impossible.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros:
A job in Higher education, so learning at the job is a perk
The professor I worked under was exceptionally kind and fair
cons:
This is a mandatory role, as a graduate student - i.e. forced labour
The President's relationship to TAs was extremely antagonistic (google 2015 UofT Strike)

review_title: I have grown significantly at the expense of so much expectation and hard work.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Toronto, ON
pros: Speaking of reasrarch, a high standard of quality and ambition around will affect who you will become. It brings opportunities to interact and know others and to see more of the field. Employers would value being exposed to such an environment.
cons: Hard work with relatively low payment (in research context). Difficult to commute to downtown Toronto.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work until the Steelworkers ruined it
pros:
Great benefits
Flextime
Free tuition to Graduate level
Excellent work life balance
cons:
Union came in the late 1990s and handcuffed employees.  If you like to go above and beyond and make a meaning contribution, you'll get chewed out by the union.

Pay is way below market

pros: It was a great company to work for with lots of learning capacity. Jobs are unionised but they can sack you if they find that they don't need the job any longer.  The working environment is friendly and supportive.
cons: The management style and structure is flawed.  There is more of a top down approach to managing employees.  Can be tough to get approval for projects as there is a lot of administrative red tape.

review_title: My experience as a research assistant was invaluable.
pros:
- Network with some of the greatest professors in North America
- Experience hands on research in the field
- Have the possibility of getting your work published
cons:
- Your work ethic is noted by the people who evaluate you in your grades
- Sometimes a lack of resources to complete work can happen

job_title: PhD Research Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros: good lab to work with. convenient location. great colleagues and professors. lots of presentation and learning opportunities. leading edge equipments and techniques
cons: working as a research assistant, the salary can not be compared to a position in the industry.  many of the postdoc or research assistant positions are under term contract, not permanent.

pros:
- Prestigious research institution with lots of hard resources to mine
- Generally amicable working environment with peers (Graduate students)
- Convenient location Downtown Toronto
cons:
- Academic hierarchy at times impede research progress
- Bad "corporate management" -> importance of researching/teaching assistant roles greatly undermined financially in order to create budget to attract higher tier researchers internationally

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros: The university of Toronto is a great institution for graduate students. There is incredible research being done in every field.
cons: Because it's so big it can sometimes be hard to find help if you need it.    Also there are a lot of admin rules in some departments

pros: Great benefits and learning opportunities.
cons: Interview process can be a bit biased and the University should work on hiring the best qualified prospects for management, as that is lacking. Seems like who you know is the rule of the day to getting hired. It can take qualified contract or temporary staff several years to get internal full-time status.

pros: Decent benefits, 3 different shifts, not bad money.
cons: Terrible management. Supervisors who have never done the job themselves therefore they know nothing about the job ! The students COMPLETELY RUN the university !!! You must try to clean washrooms with people inside them !! You are treated like the scum of the earth !!! Other than that it’s nice Lol

review_title: Very friendly and inclusive environment to work in
pros: The managers and fellow coworkers are all very friendly and try to help you to the best of their abilities. They respect you as a person and don't treat you badly just because you might be lower in ranking than them.
cons: Some students are not the most respectful and might be hard to work with sometimes.

review_title: It was a good first job, with pretty low pay, but it was a no-experience-necessary student job. It was also my first job
pros: Pay is OK for the job that I did. Supervisor is friendly and understanding. Flexible part-time schedule.
cons: There was room to slack and the slackers usually got away with it. The pay tends to be on the low to average side when it comes to low level jobs. I also feel like they overpay the upper-level jobs.

review_title: Long time to completion of studies.
pros: It has a strong name that's recognized internationally. World class research is done here.
cons: They take advantage of their graduate students - longer lengths of PhD studies compared to other schools. They get the most out of their students (cheap labour) which is probably how they have such a strong name in research.

review_title: Review of the University of Toronto Civil Engineering Faculty
job_title: Transportation Planning Intern in Toronto, ON
pros: Good training and experience in the field. I learned quite a bit from my two mentors who are professional engineers.
cons: We needed to have funding in order to receive an update on our outdated equipment that was so old and falling apart.

job_title: Medical Administrative Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros: Company as a whole is great to work for, great benefits, support from HR and lots to see and do around campus!
cons: Health and wellness department is run by a hierarchy and this does not allow for staff to have any effective input. Procedures should be put in place based on what staff advise, not solely based on what management thinks is best.

review_title: They provided good opportunities to interact with graduate students.
pros: They provide many resources, which enable a lot of tests, data collection and anlaysis.  The management staffs were excellent and kind.
cons: There are a lot of tasks to be completed.  This required addtional work at home or sometimes longer hours at the campus.

pros:
Excellent research facilities and reputation 
Availability of shared resources (equipment, analysis tools, statistical consulting, etc.)
Access to University recreation, libraries, affiliated social activities
cons:
"Multidisciplinary" is more of a buzzword than a reality.
Research groups are rather "siloed" vs. open to collaboration and shared work.
Such a large university results in layers of bureaucracy and lag time in administrative tasks.

job_title: Metallurgical and Materials Engineer in Toronto, ON
pros: Easy access in friendly media while reasonable salary and very prestigious job. Dealing with variety of academician and industry fellows.
cons: Being always updated while walking at the edge of science, commercialization of scientific findings. Shortness of research budget and lacking huge sponsor companies is now the generic challenge of researches in academic places even in the most well-known of them i.e. U of T.

pros: I worked in a summer research lab during the past summer. It was great experience, people here were nice and friendly and I was working for an engineering project so everything was pretty well.
cons: I don't particularly find anything too disturbing. Everything went well the environemnt was friendly and nice and we had to report our progress once a week which was a good track of the project.

pros: Challenging and rewarding work. Good principal.  Reasonable pay. They believe in contributing to the community at large and have a very sound educational philosophy
cons: School is underfunded and therefore administrative support is weak. The general studies textbooks tend to be old and a little out of date.

review_title: The best place you can work as a student
job_title: Peer Career Advisor in Toronto, ON
pros:
- your supervisors are like a teacher; in fact, my supervisors did their masters in Adult Education
- Care about your learning experience
cons:
- I can't think of any... 
- the only cons of working at U of T is that you have to deal with some of 'immature' students

review_title: Dynamic and exciting place to work
pros:
Smart faculty, and high level culture.

The bar for success is very very high. As long as one is willing to work hard then he is likely to do well.
cons:
Very competitive, even among members of the same department.

People step on others toes often, and this can create a tense environment.

pros: You can choose a project to work interests you in most cases, in contrast to being given a project you don't care about in industry. You can then guide the project in such a way that you acquire skills that are important for your career or a future job you want to land.
cons: Tenured profs can be less hands on about your work. Pay is probably just below what you need to get by.

pros:
great community 
learning skills 
strong leadership
great opportunities  
i really enjoyed the overall experience
cons: I could have had  little more guidance on how to follow up with certain tasks, as i was unsure if there were some people who were aware what was going on

review_title: Being a researcher means more than money
pros: you meet a lot of professors
cons: they are so keen on not expanding their connections and can not help you with finding a better future opportunity. they do not so much care about the future of their own students and everything is on you as a researcher or visiting fellow.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Toronto, ON
pros: Great place to work, lots of teaching opportunities in general due to large university size (an on three of the U of T campuses)  (great for CV building). Great teaching resources and a great community of fellow instructors.
cons: None. It is hard for grads to get this amount of teaching experience under their belt normally in other Universities and I am continually thankful for my time working at U of T.

pros: Part of a union, so benefits and pay are good. Expectations, hours, and workload are generally very reasonable. Supervisors are friendly and easy to work with.
cons: Workload varies quite a bit over the course of an academic term. Depending on the size of the course and the nature of assignments, marking get be very tedious.

pros: Some of the faculty are very approachable, kind, and look out for the students. Best part of experience is interacting with professors about your research.
cons: Overall excessive politics, lack of focus on efficiency, and lack of professionalism. Environment is highly stifling, and passive-aggressive blame-shifting is rampant. Don't know how anyone can be expected to stay for 2-3, let alone 4-7 years.

pros: Well funded, highly regarded institution with a massive variety of experts and fields to work from. Staff compensation can include tuition waivers as well for continuing education which is an excellent employee perk
cons: Absolutely massive bureaucracy that can be very difficult to navigate from a staff perspective. Faculty have a tendency to view staff in a very pejorative and dismissive way in some Faculty/Colleges

pros: Good university but have to be in the wright field so that once you graduate you are not in  trouble looking for a job.
cons: The salaries if you are postdoc is low, and it is often hard to imagine a future but that might be true for any postdoc position.

review_title: Used to be good. New director, new politics.
pros:
Pay is decent for the work.
Holidays are a plus.
Free work phone. 
Somewhat laid back environment
Job security is there.
cons:
Tons of micromanagement.
Kids of bureaucracy.
Managers steal ideas from employees and give no credit to employee except when the manager messes up.

pros: I am a current student at University of Toronto. I am glad that I chose this school to study. I met with really amazing people!
cons: It is a really challenging school. 95% of the TAs are awful and not being able to explain even the basic stuff.

review_title: The job position is definitely worth taking if you don't mind spending 24/7 hours with kids
pros: The job is very entertaining and has a range of different activities. Counsellors attend all of the places with kids for free (e.g. Case Loma, Niagara Falls, etc) and accommodation is free
cons: This job position might be tiring, as it requires a lot of energy. High-stress situations might arise as well, so you need to be prepared

pros:
- Great city
- Cutting edge research
- President Gertler truly listens
cons:
- Administration takes faculty for granted
- High cost of living
- Endless bureaucratic hurdles
- Students served on a customer model, rather than an educational model
- Very high turnaround of staff; many faculty see this place as a stepping stone to a greater American university

pros: Good salary and good people. Also provides good benefit packages and working environment. So, I would recommend working for U of T.
cons: Not enough employee development opportunities, at least comparing to University of British Columbia. But, I only work part-time. Full-time staff might have better career development support.

pros: Great experience working at on the best institutions in Canada.
cons:
Very challenging given the students in the class (specially if it's an undergrad course);
Low pay considering the amount of work required (specially if it's ones first time teaching the course)

review_title: Detail oriented job, quiet but good. Need to be good at customer service and communication.
job_title: Student Library Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros: Quiet space and positive environment. Place where you can chat and study. Learn many good skills for the future. Place to learn computer and customer service skills.
cons: Many rules to keep in mind, sometimes harder to catch on to at first if not prone to being detail oriented

pros:
- Great level of science.
- Many opportunities to collaborate within the University and associated hospitals.
- St George campus is located right in the city downtown and in a booming ecosystem networking with people working at startups, hospitals and other organizations.
cons: Some benefits for Postdocs have been negotiated via collective agreements, but postdocs still are way behind other employee groups with similar or even lower educational levels at the University of Toronto.

pros: There is a great variety of jobs in all fields of work, the working conditions are excellent, the pay is fair and benefits including pension are very good
cons: There aren't a lot of cons with working at the University. The fact that the main campus is in the downtown core of the city means transportation to and from work can at times be very challenging and/or expensive.

pros:
