- The pay is pretty high.
- CS Dept. has enough positions for all Grads and PhD.
- The professors are really cool.
cons:
- The semesters are very short to introduce anything new.
- If you think you go with a mindset of changing things around, then that's not gonna happen.
- They are running on ages old technologies.

job_title: Associate, Information, Registration and Membership Services in Toronto, ON
pros:
Easy going, friendly people to work with (other students)
An overall great place to be and spend time while a student
cons: No job growth for casual staff, probably the reason why everyone is so cool, because there's no competition, it's just a student job and everyone knows that

review_title: Hon B. Sc. and PhD in life sciences at U of T St. George
pros:
Beautiful campus
World class faculty
Excellent library system, with extensive subscriptions
Diversity of courses and programs offered
cons:
Too many students in life sciences
Multiple choice tests in first and second year
Large commuter student population, which dilutes the campus experience
Heavy course load and lower GPAs in some specializations compared to similar programs at other Universities.

job_title: PhD Student In Engineering in Toronto, ON
pros:
- Lots of professional development programs
- Number of TA positions
- Great place to learn and grow
cons:
- Too little leaning experience from research supervisors 
- Tenured supervisors can treat students as slaves and no one can stop them
- Too much waste of time and  growth curve is very very low

pros: Very flexible environment to grow and learn. Weekly schedules are also very flexible and can change weekly if needed and option to work from home occasionally.
cons: Very high pressure job to maintain. There is always work to be done and sometimes it gets really overwhelming to handle.

review_title: Postdoctoral Fellow at U of T
pros: Good venue, great flexibility, nice management.
cons: Postdocs are very unprotected and have neither student nor employer tax benefits despite the legal ruling of Ontario that they should be legally recognized as employees.

pros: Great and understanding managers. Enforces responsibility and other transferable soft skills into individuals. Great feedback process.
cons: Inservice can be tiring. Supervisors are very strict (not without cause) to employees.Because students with work experienced worked here, no one was ever unprofessional or unpleasant.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Toronto, ON
pros:
- great food all around
- best research labs in Canada
- PI was extremely friendly and engaged with my work
cons:
- Long hours, typically 60+/week
- Pay is horrific, but that is "grad student life"
- You have to go on strike to try and get any pay raise

pros: good benefits, oppotunities to be promoted, great resources, and friendly environment. The work place is not intense but still make people productive
cons: University work sometimes can be very stressful, especially if you are still in the course of trying to make everything on track.

review_title: Not a bad place to work.
pros: Good environment. Good people. Good benefits and salary if you are lucky to get a full time/permanent position.
cons: Extremely unionized environment. Growth especially from part-time to full-time/permanent is stunted because of this. You receive no benefits until you become a full-time/permanent staff.

pros: People are good to work with. Technology is ever changing and improving. Lots to do and see and learn.
cons: No support from the high ups. Rules change daily. If they don't like you they find a reason to make your life miserable.

review_title: An okay place to work for Admin Assistant (keeps defaulting to Improvement Engineer)
job_title: Continuous Improvement Engineer in Toronto, ON
pros: Campus is lovely, UofT has great benefits, pay is good.
cons: A lot of bullying and intimidation and harassment from management is tolerated. Favouritism as well. If you have health issues or need to take a leave of absence they will try to get rid of you. I do think this depends on department you work in.

review_title: I returned to do a master's degree after being out of school for 9 years. I worked as teaching assistance.
pros: Campus is right downtown! The staff was helpful, the students awesome to work with, professors maintain rigorous academic program.
cons: Work-life balance is hard to manage. The workload was high to manage my own course work with work for teaching assistant position.

pros: interactions with students from different departments and from different years; opportunity to apply what I learned in class at the lab
cons: the pay is not much in comparison to the work efforts, but that should not be a  primary concern

review_title: Come for the name, stay for the benefits
pros: Benefits are great! Pay isn't the greatest but flexible working environment and a unionized working environment helps. Not all bosses are flexible though.
cons: Don't fully utilize staff who can contribute much more. Same group of people are tapped into for joining committees and providing input- a sort of cliquish environment, which helps create silos and an unfriendly working environment.

pros:
- Compensation is absolutely fantastic
- Most people I have worked with are very genuine, and hard working
- Endless opportunities to converse with various academics
cons:
- None
- Parking is a bit expensive

pros: Best institution for Machine Learning and Deep Learning in the world, and very friendly atmosphere for doing research.
cons: The salary is not that high compared with phd students in America. and you have to pay the extra tuition yourself.

pros: Flexible hours, travel (bi-annually) for conferences, rewarding work.
cons: Work load, to progress not based on merit (it is based on the time spent), collaborations are often forced and not wanted (do not provide benefit and often result in more work), if you are good at your job you will get more work (not rewarded).

review_title: Prefer not to answer, very specific
pros: Learning environment, vacation, benefits
cons: some departments are not so nice to work in, there is a lot of tension with management and the union, a bit of a "golden handcuffs" - you get entrenched in your job and other departments have difficulty seeing transferable skills, hard to leave

job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in Toronto, ON
pros: The University of Toronto comes with brand recognition around the world, opens up lots of opportunities. In engineering, the level of equipment and access is pretty good. There is a good opportunity to collaborate with others within the University and outside. Support staff is really good. The campus is located in downtown Toronto, and so is easy to access.
cons: Competitive to get in.

pros: Teaching assistants get free spending account of $800-100% coverage in terms of dental, medical care. You can even buy prescription sunglasses with this insurance as long as you work 50 hours or longer.
cons:
Long hours of preparation
No formal training before induction
They typically don't hire undergraduate students for certain programs

review_title: Relaxed and open environment, exciting work, steeped in academia
pros: Dynamic, small-sized classes with great speaker events, big ideas and networking opportunities with many academics and professionals in the political and public sphere
cons: Small classes mean a small staff size but as they're increasing their enrollment more positions should be available.

review_title: Super challenging culture for anyone in a non-academic role/division
pros: It's so big that you can be exposed to lots of opportunities for growth and different kinds of people
cons: The office culture in non-academic roles/divisions is cut-throat and selfish

pros:
People working there are very smart and it is a fast pace working environment. We will learn a lot.
It is very fast to get the working permit.
cons: The salary is quite low and it is very difficult to get a permanent position at the university and whatever the campus.

review_title: Postdocs are at the bottom of the totem pole here, lower than undergrads, even.
pros: Library access. Centrally located in the city.
cons: Expensive gym memberships that don't count across different facilities. No good benefits. Forced yearly "fees" (we literally pay a fee for the 'privilege' of working at UofT). No housing assistance. Food options on campus are terrible (and expensive). No commuting benefits.

pros:
Very highly research based. It is top 10 in the world due to it's research professors. 
Definitely recommend doing research here. 
All computer science researchers meet up once a week for presentation
cons:
High expectations. To get a research position, must have a high grade. 
Low pay for research

pros:
- Access to incredibly smart individuals
- Fairly easy to reach out to any professor at the institution
- Hands off approach lets you learn a lot of stuff
cons:
- Pretty poor compensation, but as a first year intern, couldn't complain too much
- It is some difficult and esoteric work, so be prepared to spend a lot of time just learning material

pros: UofT is a great place to learn. I was lucky to be able to work with and Lear from very talented colleagues.
cons: Sink or swim kind of place, and stressful. Guaranteed funding capped at five years for PhD candidates. Many candidates(~30%) quit the program before they finish.

pros:
- Competitive salary
- Good working hours
- Reasonably fair management, depending on the faculty
cons:
- Activities move slowly here
- Small operating budgets & provides very little equipment to staff (E.g. WFH is on your own devices)
- Not a lot of opportunities to work on large projects

review_title: It is part of my Master of Applied Science Program.
pros:
1. Reputation of the university and the supervisor (Prof. Wonham)
2. Good academic atmosphere and working environment
3. Good training and preparation for future career
cons: Did not get a chance to do interships as an international master student.

pros: The  University of  Toronto provided a great opportunity to learn and lead. There were many opportinuities for exposure to cutting edge research.  Having a great PI was critical.
cons: Contract nature of work made long term stability impossible.  Tranistory nature of  working with students meant that culture changes would occur with student turn over.

job_title: Course Instructor, TA, RA, Phd Student in Toronto, ON
pros: I have the chance to work with some of the world's top academics, researchers, and staff.
cons: Being a TA and research assistant for multiple faculty, I am exploited and often asked to do things beyond my union-specified duties and hours. The university employs so many people, that it is made very clear that the institution does not care about its individual labourers.

pros:
A very positive experience working with department of computer science. 
The professor was very approachable. It was a departure from the typical computer science modus operandi and was a very social and interactive experience. I had a great team, and our project was a success!
cons: If you have a bad team, this could easily be a very negative experience.

review_title: I was only working there part time to supplement my income
pros: prominent school in the region
cons: large school, loose community; you may not feel as close knit as it can be as in more compact smaller schools. Of course, it's also a research university and being an instructor is not like being in a teaching university.

review_title: I expanded my professional network by attending the master program at University of Toronto
job_title: MASc Student and Teaching Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros:
A well-known university with high ranking 
Many academic experts
Various fields for research
career center for helping students in building their CVs, resumes, cover letters and job search
cons:
The courses are very theoretical 
There are few courses to teach software tools and packages used in industry (depends on the department)

review_title: Flexible, friendly, and supportive working environment
pros: In terms of research work, the pros include direct access to top-notch library resources and article collections. At the workplace one interact with people from various backgrounds, whether they are professors, students, staff, or technicians.
cons: Research assistants must work for a certain period of time to become part of the staff and receive health insurance coverage.

pros: U of T is a nice University - right downtown with lots of amenities.  As a grad student, it was great to have world renowned researchers and resources right at your fingertips.
cons: Very large, impersonal and political.  Unfortunately I had a terrible supervisor, and myself and all of her grad students got lost in the system.

pros: The good thing about being a PhD STEM student at U of T is that the stipend is guaranteed even without TAing. You also rotate in 3 different labs for your first 3 months to find the right fit for you.
cons: Tuition is high and there is not really an established alumni network, although this does vary by department.

review_title: Ph.D. student in MIE of University of Toronto
pros: The faculty members of the department are usually very helpful and easy-going.
cons: The administrative part of the department is not as good as its faculty side. Staff here are not willing to help if you ask for something that is not routinely done in their everyday's work.

review_title: Okay institution, poor pay for graduate students
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Toronto, ON
pros:
Lots of collaborations available
Ability to work with world-class researchers and research facilities
cons:
A large institution with lots of bureaucracy for graduate students. 
Very lengthy graduate degrees (7+ years for some departments)
Graduate awards (NSERC, Etc.) are often additional pay to students and instead used to cover stipend. 
The stipend is low for the living costs in Toronto.

pros:
one of the most prestigious places to work in Canada
huge work place; 3 campuses
great learning environment and very diverse group of employees and students
cons: generally, treat employees well but as teaching assistant not much additional compensation except for hourly wage; sometimes don`t really feel appreciated

review_title: Not a great place if you are looking for a career; unionized jobs with a weak union.
pros: Discounts on tuition fees; free undergraduate tuition for children.
cons: Poor health and pension plan; low wages; routine, unpaid, overtime.

pros: Good pay, excellent actually, hours and benefits are always top notch, work load not too heavy, requirements not too big, relaxed and academic environment, very nice colleagues and managers.
cons: N/A for me but may be more respect to lower level employees, we cannot be all professors

pros:
- Access to incredibly smart individuals
- Fairly easy to reach out to any professor at the institution
- Hands off approach lets you learn a lot of stuff
cons:
- Pretty poor compensation, but as a first year intern, couldn't complain too much
- It is some difficult and esoteric work, so be prepared to spend a lot of time just learning material

pros:
You can get your Post-Graduate degree while working as a research and teaching assistant.
You are provided with your workplace/office and the time schedule is flexible.
cons:
The compensation is low considering the fact that you have to pay for your tuition fees. 
The work/life balance may be difficult to kept during the terms that you attend courses.

job_title: Student Library Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros: Excellent employers when it comes to accommodating student schedules and providing thorough training to students. As a former employee, I acquired skills that I believe will serve me well for years to come.
cons: Frequent periods of self-directed work when projects and maintenance work have been completed. Not necessarily a con, but something to consider when applying.

pros: Good working atmosphere. Supervisors are very nice. Manager is approachable. Flexible hours! Good for students as they are understanding.
cons: Bad hours - evening shifts are compulsory. The pay is not that great at all. Very boring work and repetitive.

review_title: great place to be, not great benefits for postdocs.
job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in Toronto, ON
pros: toronto's wonderful, the school is great, the students (if you have them) are serious.
cons: postdocs have a weird status here which means that at times we're treated like grad students, and our benefits resemble student benefits. for example, i've actually had to pay for for dental here than in the US.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros:
- Great opportunity to earn some money while in school at UofT
- Always looks good on a resume, and provides valuable research experience
- Flexible hours
cons:
- Experience can be entirely dependent on the professor(s) you are working with. 
- Base pay is low compared to the rate that teaching assistants make, despite similar workloads.

review_title: The best way to learn is by teaching
pros: Great atmosphere and sense of community as class size wasn't very large. The course was a fourth year robotics course and involved a final competition for the students.
cons: Some of the workspace was under construction and the computers were not always up to date. Sometimes other classes would leave a mess.
